information:
As of mid-May 2025, New York Yankees player Aaron Judge's batting average was reported at various points between .402 and .423. On May 17, after a 2-for-4 game, his average reached .414, though a subsequent 0-for-5 game lowered it. By May 18, Judge had accumulated 15 home runs and 41 RBI for the season, leading the league in several offensive categories. An analysis by MLB.com noted that achieving a .414 batting average with over 15 home runs within a team's first 44 games is a rare historical feat, with parallels to seasons by Mickey Mantle in 1956 and Manny Ramirez in 2001.

According to a list of National League batting leaders published on May 18, 2025, Freddie Freeman of the Los Angeles Dodgers was leading with a .375 average. Other top hitters included Will Smith (Los Angeles Dodgers) at .336, Brendan Donovan (St. Louis Cardinals) at .330, and Manny Machado (San Diego Padres) at .323. In the American League, David Alonso of the New York Mets had a team-high batting average of .308 as of May 17. In Triple-A, Chicago Cubs prospect Matt Shaw was reported to be hitting .400 over his last eight games.

The last Major League Baseball player to finish a season with a batting average of .400 or higher was Ted Williams, who hit .406 in 1941. One analysis noted that modern players face challenges in reaching this mark, such as higher strikeout rates; early in the 2025 season, Aaron Judge had 31 strikeouts, whereas Williams had only 27 in his entire 1941 season. Another factor is Batting Average on Balls In Play (BABIP). The major league-wide BABIP in 2025 is .288, compared to .300 in 1930. In 2000, Ichiro Suzuki recorded a .387 batting average but was limited to 105 games due to an injury.

forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Aaron Judge's batting average, currently the only one near .400, regresses toward the mean over the next two weeks due to a few average-to-poor games, and he finishes May with an average below the .400 threshold. No other player gets close.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Aaron Judge sustains his exceptional performance for another two weeks, avoiding any significant slumps and maintaining a batting average at or above .400 through the games played up to June 1, 2025.
forecast.rationale: My forecast of 30% reflects the fact that while one player, Aaron Judge, is currently flirting with the .400 mark, maintaining such a high average is historically rare and statistically unlikely, even over a short period. The primary factor driving this forecast is the strong statistical principle of regression to the mean. Judge is an elite hitter, but his current performance is a significant outlier compared to his career norms. A single hitless game, such as his recent 0-for-5, can cause a substantial drop in his average, demonstrating the volatility involved. The outcome of this question rests almost entirely on his ability to continue an exceptional hot streak. No other player is realistically in contention; the next closest, Freddie Freeman at .375, would need an unprecedented surge to reach .400 in two weeks. Furthermore, modern baseball, with its high strikeout rates and advanced defensive shifts, makes maintaining a high batting average more difficult than in previous eras. The last player to finish a season at .400 was Ted Williams in 1941, highlighting the immense difficulty of the feat. My probability is not lower because Judge is an exceptionally talented player who is currently performing at this level, and he only needs to sustain it for another 13 days, a relatively short timeframe. This makes the outcome plausible. My probability is not higher because of the overwhelming statistical and historical precedent against it, the high volatility of batting averages, and the near-total dependence on a single player avoiding any kind of slump or injury. I would increase my forecast if Judge posts several multi-hit games early this week, pushing his average to .420 or higher, creating a buffer. Conversely, I would lower my forecast if his average drops into the .380s in the coming week.
